The Drilling Specialties Company- Alamo Plant (the DSC Plant), a division of Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP, is a manufacturing facility of Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP, headquartered in The Woodlands, Texas. The DSC Plant is located in Conroe, Texas and is situated on approximately 44 acres. The DSC Plant began production of Soltex Additive in batch operations in 1978, and was then owned by Chromalloy. The facility was sold in 1983, to Drilling Specialties Co. LLC, a subsidiary of Phillips Petroleum Company.  In 1987 the DSC Plant converted to continuous operations.  The facility is currently a division of the Chevron Phillips Chemical Company, LP as the result of a joint venture in 2001.



The DSC Plant is required to prepare a Risk Management Plan (RMP) because the facility stores and uses Sulfur Trioxide in excess of the threshold quantity listed in 40 CFR Part 68. The DSC Plant uses Sulfur Trioxide (SO3) to manufacture Soltex Additive, a drilling mud additive. The DSC Plant is subject to the RMP Program 3 reporting requirements as defined in 40 CFR Part 68 because the facility is also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard set forth  in 29 CFR Subpart 1910.119.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



Process Safety Management at the DSC Plant complies with the requirements of both the OSHA PSM Standard and EPA RMP regulation.  As detailed in site procedure HSE600 RMP, the DSC Plant manages process safety through employee participation.   Some of the details of this management system include:



Process Safety Management at the DSC Plant complies with the requirements of both the OSHA PSM Standard and EPA RMP regulation.  As detailed in site procedure for RMP program, the DSC Plant manages process safety through employee participation.   Some of the details of this management system include:



1) Employee Participation is outlined in Process Safety Management site procedure, which is

focused on driving safety behavior by individual work groups on safety activities and issues in their area.

2) Process Safety Information is outlined in Process Safety Management site procedure.   Process Safety Management assigns PSM element responsible positions to each type of information item of process safety compliance documentation.

3) Management of Design and Process Hazards procedure  provides site-specific details on the conduct and disposition of all unit PHAs and references to corporate PHA procedures, all of which provide oversight and management of the performance of PHAs and include relevant timelines for report development and review, recommendation development and tracking and final report issuance. The corporate procedures for conduct of PHAs and the qualitative assessment of risk include consideration of off-site consequences and harm to the environment or the public.

4) All operating procedures are developed, reviewed and kept current by personnel experienced in the operation of that portion of the plant or in that job or task.  Operating procedures are developed and managed according to the site's policy OWI003 Process for Updating all Procedures and Associated Documents.   

5) Training for process operators is managed by the DSC Training Coordinator and includes initial hire or job transfer training with classroom and on-the-job elements and ongoing refresher training for experienced personnel on a frequency determined by individual need or on a maximum three-year cycle.

6) The site Mechanical Integrity Program encompasses all the functional groups of the Maintenance

Department and includes written procedures for maintenance activities as well as inspection and testing schedules, procedures and reports as required by both PSM and RMP. 

7) Changes to equipment or operations in a covered process follow site procedure SLP600 Management

of Change Process (MOC).  A company-wide software system aids in managing such changes and provides a me

ans of controlling the change process through the required safety and health evaluation, appropriate approvals, and the pre-startup safety review steps.

8) The facility's MOC procedure includes Pre-startup Safety Review (PSSR) details on requirements for and how to conduct a pre-startup safety.  Review for changes requiring this type of follow-up to ensure system integrity before introduction of hazardous chemicals.

9) Audits for compliance with both the PSM and RMP regulatory requirements are conducted at least every three years pursuant to the corporate auditing protocol. Some audits or evaluations of individual process safety elements may be conducted in the intervening years according to a specific need for that area.

10) Incidents that occur in a covered process are investigated through application of site procedure, Near Miss and Incident Investigation, which provides guidance on the use of the appropriate investigation method as well as development of investigation reports and corrective actions or recommendations to prevent recurrence. A company-wide software system aids in tracking both the investigations and the resulting recommendations and their resolution.

11) The site safe work practices are managed through several procedures including General Plant Safety Rules, Hot Work Permits, Lockout Tag out Procedure, and Confined Space Entry.

12) Management of contract employees follows site procedure Contractor Safety Program, which includes selection of contractors based on their safety performance, training of contract workers on the hazards where they will be working in the plant and periodic evaluation of the performance of both the individual contract employees and the contract company in general at the DSC plant.

13) The DSC plant has developed an Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) to guide responses to various types of emergencies and events. This ICP includes procedures on responding to hazardous material releases, both large and small, and coordin

ation with on- and off-site responders.

The DSC plant became an OSHA STAR worksite in the Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) in 2012.  The site was originally certified as a STAR worksite in 2008. This voluntary program is a partnership between OSHA and industry to recognize and encourage excellence and continuous improvement in safety programs. STAR certification represents the highest form of recognition OSHA can give a company for outstanding safety performance.



CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTIONS:



The Chemical specific preventions for SO3 unloading include using two operators to start the unloading process, clear the line, connect and disconnect lines and purging.  At least one operator is in attendance during the entire SO3 unloading process, which allows for isolation of the system remotely if needed.  An automatic shut-off valve is mounted at the unloading station to quickly shutoff the unloading process if needed. The unloading hoses are stainless steel braided hoses with additional support to prevent unnecessary binding or crimping. The transfer hoses are replaced every year to ensure hose integrity.  Video camera monitoring by the control room allows for an additional set of eyes to monitor system integrity during unloading operation.   The DSC Plant also consults with external subject matter experts on the safe handling and storage of SO3 to ensure the facility's equipment and practices are up-to-date with the manufacturers recommended best practices.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Alarm Systems 

The DSC Plant has an internal plant wide alarm system for fires and emergencies.  



Emergency Responders

The DSC Plant has an Emergency Response Plan for handling releases of hazardous substances. The plan provides the DSC Plant with a system of readiness which includes procedures for the orderly transition from normal to emergency operations, a design for delegation of emergency authority and responsibility, a method for interfacing with other emergency

organizations and a means of controlling the emergency. The DSC Plant's emergency organization is structured according to the Incident Command Center (ICC), so all aspects of internal and external emergencies are addressed. The Emergency Response Plan also incorporates pre-emergency planning via the use of monthly What-If scenarios and emergency response drills that include event simulation and actual hands-on training.



Communications Link to Offsite Responders

The DSC ICC is the central communication point for any emergencies that may occur at the facility. The ICC is staffed by Management, and Environmental, Health & Safety personnel, as well as individuals who are on call for the facility Incident Command System.  Local emergency assistance is obtained by calling 911.  The DSC Plant Safety Representative participates with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  Additionally, the DSC Plant hosts local area fire department tours to familiarize local area fire departments with the DSC Plant layout.  



On Site Fire Protection Equipment

A plant fire water system with ground-level fire monitors.





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Accidents with On-Site Effects

On May 19, 2011, a small Sulfur Trioxide (SO3) leak occurred at a hose connection while unloading an SO3 railcar. One employee was injured and treated beyond first aid, including days away from work.   No significant property damage on-site or off-site impacts occurred as part of this incident.



Accidents with Off-Site Effects

There were no accidents with off-site effects in the last five years involving SO3.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 



As part of the DSC Plant's commitment to continuous improvement, a number  of initiatives and measures that have been implemented to enhance the safety of the facility's processes.  For example, the DSC Plant has a proactive Structure Safety Process that utilizes various techniques for the identification, assessment and control of conditions that

may adversely impact employees, company assets, the public or the environment. All employees at the DSC Plant actively participate in the identification of hazards and risks via the use of Accident Prevention Techniques, Task Safety Observations and Job Safety Analyses.   All employees at the DSC Plant are encouraged to identify and recommend corrections to any unsafe work practices, procedures and equipment that they identify.  All recommendations are discussed by DSC Plant management during monthly employee meetings and suggested improvements to enhance plant safety are continuously evaluated and where applicable, adopted and implemented.
